title: Towards Theoretically Understanding Why Sgd Generalizes Better Than Adam in Deep Learning

sections.introduction:
Stochastic gradient descent (Sgd)Â   has become one of the most popular algorithms for training deep neural networksÂ       . In spite of its simplicity and effectiveness, SgdÂ uses one learning rate for all gradient coordinates and could suffer from unsatisfactory convergence performance, especially for ill-conditioned problemsÂ . To avoid this issue, a variety of adaptive gradient algorithms have been developed that adjust learning rate for each gradient coordinate according to the current geometry curvature of the objective function    . These algorithms, especially for Adam, have achieved much faster convergence speed than vanilla SgdÂ in practice. Despite their faster convergence behaviors, these adaptive gradient algorithms usually suffer from worse generalization performance than SgdÂ   . Specifically, adaptive gradient algorithms often show faster progress in the training phase but their performance quickly reaches a plateaus on test data. Differently, SgdÂ usually improves model performance slowly but could achieve higher test performance.
One empirical explanationÂ [ref]1  0 1 for this generalization gap is that adaptive gradient algorithms
tend to converge to sharp minima whose local basin has large curvature and usually generalize poorly, while SgdÂ prefers to find flat minima
and thus generalizes better.
However, recent evidenceÂ  2 shows that (1) for deep neural networks, the minima at the asymmetric basins/valleys where both steep and flat directions exist also generalize well though they are sharp in terms of their local curvature, and (2) SgdÂ often converges to these minima. So the argument of the conventional â€œflat" and â€œsharp" minima defined on curvature cannot explain these new results. Thus the reason for the generalization gap between adaptive gradient methods and SgdÂ is still unclear. In this work, we provide a new viewpoint for understanding the generalization performance gap. We first formulate AdamÂ and SgdÂ as LÃ©vy-driven stochastic differential equations (SDEs), since the SDE of an algorithm shares similar convergence behaviors of the algorithm and can be analyzed more easily than directly analyzing the algorithm. Then we analyze the escaping behaviors of these SDEs at local minima to investigate the generalization gap between AdamÂ and Sgd, as escaping behaviors determine which basin that an algorithm finally converges to and thus affect the generalization performance of the algorithm. By analysis, we find that compared with Adam, SgdÂ is more locally unstable and is more likely to converge to the minima at the flat or asymmetric basins/valleys which often have better generalization performance over other type minima. So our results can explain the better generalization performance of SgdÂ over Adam. Our contributions are highlighted below. Firstly, this work is the first one that adopts LÃ©vy-driven SDE which better characterizes the algorithm gradient noise in practice, to analyze the adaptive gradient algorithms. Specifically, Fig.Â 1 shows that the gradient noise in AdamÂ and Sgd, i.e.Â the difference between the full and stochastic gradients, has heavy tails and can be well characterized by systemic Î±ğ›¼\alpha-stable (ğ’®â€‹Î±â€‹ğ’®ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®\mathcal{S}\alpha\mathcal{S}) distributionÂ 4.
Based on this observation, we view AdamÂ and SgdÂ as discretization of the continuous-time processes and formulate the processes as LÃ©vy-driven SDEs to analyze their behaviors. Compared with Gaussian gradient noise assumption in SgdÂ 5 6 7, ğ’®â€‹Î±â€‹ğ’®ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®\mathcal{S}\alpha\mathcal{S} distribution assumption can characterize the heavy-tailed gradient noise in practice more accurately as shown in Fig.Â 1, and also better explains the different generalization performance of SgdÂ and AdamÂ as discussed in Sec.Â 3.
This work extends 3 8 from SgdÂ on the over-simplified one-dimensional problems to much more complicated adaptive algorithms on high-dimensional problems. It also differs fromÂ 9, as 9 considers escaping behaviors of SgdÂ along several fixed directions, while this work analyzes the dynamic underlying structures in gradient noise that plays an important role in the local escaping behaviors of both AdamÂ andÂ Sgd. Next, we theoretically prove that for the LÃ©vy-driven SDEs of AdamÂ and Sgd, their escaping time Î“Î“\Gamma from a local basin ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega}, namely the least time for escaping from the inner of ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega} to its outside, is at the order of ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµâˆ’Î±/mâ€‹(ğ“¦))ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€ğ›¼ğ‘šğ“¦\mathcal{O}({\varepsilon^{-\alpha}}\!/m(\bm{\mathcal{W}})), where the constant Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01{\varepsilon}\!\in\!(0,1) relies on the learning rate of algorithms and Î±ğ›¼\alpha denotes the tail index of ğ’®â€‹Î±â€‹ğ’®ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®\mathcal{S}\alpha\mathcal{S} distribution. Here mâ€‹(ğ“¦)ğ‘šğ“¦m(\bm{\mathcal{W}}) is a non-zero Radon measure on the escaping set ğ“¦ğ“¦\bm{\mathcal{W}} of AdamÂ  and SgdÂ  at the local basin ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega} (see Sec.Â 4.1), and actually negatively relies on the Radon measure of ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega}. So both AdamÂ and SgdÂ have small escaping time at the â€œsharp" minima whose corresponding basins ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega} have small Radon measure. It means that AdamÂ and SgdÂ are actually unstable at â€œsharp" minima and would escape them to â€œflatter" ones. Note, the Radon measure of ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega} positively depends on the volume of ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega}. So these results also well explain the observations inÂ [ref]1  0 1 that the minima of deep networks found by SgdÂ often locate at the flat or asymmetric valleys, as their corresponding basins have large volumes and thus large Radon measure. Finally, our results can answer why SgdÂ often converges to flatter minima than AdamÂ in terms of Radon measure, and thus explain the generalization gap between AdamÂ and Sgd. Firstly, our analysis shows that even for the same basin ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega}, AdamÂ often has smaller Radon measure mâ€‹(ğ“¦)ğ‘šğ“¦m(\bm{\mathcal{W}}) on the escaping set ğ“¦ğ“¦\bm{\mathcal{W}} at ğ›€ğ›€\bm{\Omega} than Sgd, as the geometry adaptation in AdamÂ via adaptively scaling each gradient coordinate well diminishes underlying anisotropic structure in gradient noise and leads to smaller mâ€‹(ğ“¦)ğ‘šğ“¦m(\bm{\mathcal{W}}).
Secondly, the empirical results in Sec.Â 5 and Fig.Â 1 show that SgdÂ often
has much smaller tail index Î±ğ›¼\alpha of gradient noise than AdamÂ for some optimization iterations and thus enjoys smaller factor Îµâˆ’Î±superscriptğœ€ğ›¼{\varepsilon^{-\alpha}}.
These results together show that SgdÂ is more locally unstable and would like to converge to flatter minima with larger measure mâ€‹(ğ“¦)ğ‘šğ“¦m(\bm{\mathcal{W}}) which often refer to the minima at the flat and asymmetric basins/valleys, according with empirical evidences inÂ  0 1 . Considering the observations inÂ [ref]1  0 1 that the minima at the flat and asymmetric basins/valleys often generalize better, our results well explain the generalization gap between AdamÂ and Sgd. Besides, our results also show that SgdÂ benefits from its anisotropic gradient noise on its escaping behaviors, while AdamÂ does not.
